topic.title: Tutorial: how to autostart zeronet on Debian with forced Tor mode
topic.body:
First install tor with 'sudo apt install tor'.
Then you have to make some modifications to tor config files, mainly uncomment two lines. Just run this:

```sudo sed -i -e 's/#\s*ControlPort 9051/ControlPort 9051/' /etc/tor/torrc```
```sudo sed -i -e 's/#\s*CookieAuthentication 1/CookieAuthentication 1/' /etc/tor/torrc```
```sudo service tor restart```
```sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor (user)```

where (user) is your linux username.


Then in Tor Browser Bundle (download from https://www.torproject.org/download/ and unpack, then run it), enter in URL bar 'about:config', search for 'network.proxy.no_proxies' and change its value to '127.0.0.1'

Then what I do is create a 'zeronet.desktop' file with contents:



**[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=zeronet
Exec=path/to/zeronet/ZeroNet.sh --tor always --open_browser asjkdjad893e893jdas
Terminal=false**


And place this file in ~/.config/autostart/


Replace path with where your ZeroNet.sh is. --tor always forces tor mode, and --open_browser (nonsense) is only there because script won't start without this argument, and nonsense prevents any browser from actually running on its own. Then when you reboot, just go to http://127.0.0.1:43110 in Tor Browser Bundle and bookmark it. Now you can always access already-started ZeroNet from there whenever you start your PC, with Tor mode forced.

If you disable javascript in Tor Browser, zeronet will whine that it needs it to run. In that case, you have to add the NoScript icon to your interface next to URL bar (just like addons in firefox) and manually allow '127.0.0.1' then refresh the page.

topic.title: Your opinion on video games
topic.body:
Are they a good form of entertainment? Are they more bad than good? Do they disconnect you from real life too much? Are they worth your time, money and enslavement by Sony/Microsoft/whatever?

I used to game a lot in my spare time, then I gradually kept losing interest and now I'm considering quitting entirely. I feel more fresh, calmer, with a clear mind, less tired, when I don't game at all during a given day.

topic.title: [PLEASE SEED] Lost All Hope - a website about suicide methods and stats
We have to convince youtubers to make privacy "cool"
topic.body:
Today I was watching a known gamer's channel where he was bragging about his new PC, audio setup, filmmaking, TV, etc. Of course Windows 10 on that PC in the background, as this is gaming PC, but he claims he uses it for serious work too (dumb fuck). Now, this is considered "cool"  among boomers, to have latest hardware and games and whatnot. 

What if we tried to spread the word so that those who spread such trends, spread ideas about digital privacy & security which is still relevant to what they usually record after all? For example, they start uploading videos saying like "guess what guys, today I found this addon for firefox that blocks even more garbage on websites" or "this VPN has a builtin killswitch which is a killer feature" or "wow, this distro named (something) is the best I used, and works OOTB without any binary blobs!".

The kiddos and smartphone addicts would then start competing for privacy, because actually once you get into it it's a very interesting journey of learning new stuff and self-improvement (something like sharing your setups on r/privacy, those guys can be competitive to the point of masturbating to the fact that my setup is 1% more private than the others).

We need more influential people to see the light, the rest will then follow.

topic.title: Is gaming a waste of time?
topic.body:
Once I got into privacy it became increasingly difficult to game since Linux is not as good as Windows for that, and even so, I wanted to avoid any and all proprietary software, which means no Steam and almost no games. Gradually I've been losing interest in gaming at all, and AAA gaming is pure cancer, with analytics, microtransactions, exclusive preorder bonuses, horrible DRMs and generally big publishers being douchebags.

Games are made so that they are as addictive as possible and ultimately you gain NOTHING of value by playing them. Looking back on it all, I wasted an extreme time on gaming when I could have been studying to get a good job, for example. And games gave me absolutely NOTHING I can be proud of or even find useful today. I think it's time to focus on more productive entertainment, such as reading, music, movies, sports, coding etc. 

Do you guys game? Do you use a separate device for it, like a console or windows laptop? Do you keep it airgapped? And what do you think about gaming generally?

1575162021_17UaTuxP639VqVnepbKXm14qsD8Fv.body:
If money is not AT ALL an issue, look into this marvel: https://www.raptorcs.com/content/base/products.html
No x86, no ME/PSP, free BIOS, free microcode, and quite powerful.

Otherwise, b4's answer is basically the only solutions we have.

> [flyingox](#comment_1_17T2nsH7uiAhVL2RwPQMgeHoaMMT7f3XUX): Simply install Linux, even simple basic installs are fairly secure.   Nearly any distro nowadays will secure you well enough that you do not have to worry too much...  Unless you are contending with hackers who are attacking your computer / system you should be fairly secure.

Software is the easy part, but hardware is a real issue. If his threat model contains government, then Intel ME/AMD PSP is out of the question, as they are gov backdoors. They can also be compromised by hackers anytime. AMD not wanting to release PSP source code makes me think it relies on security-through-obscurity, so yeah, very insecure.

To OP: if you don't need modern rig, buy a used Thinkpad and flash libreboot, or buy a laptop with disabled IME from Purism or System76. Otherwise, just use a Thinkpad with Tails for internet browsing and then build a second PC however you want, and airgap it, and do everything else there. Then you can even use Win10 safely.

There must be independently verifiable/forkable/repleceable open-source firmware. You still have to trust the manufacturer that they didn't implement a PHYSICAL backdoor at some point in production (as in, built-in to the silicon) but it's still way more safe than current situation with Shintel and Fuck 'em D

> [edgelordofdecent](#comment_298_1PGTHAmvu7K2PM7qqfoKyWv69aJsAaJQp5): Uses intel. Intel ME included. Problem

no. intel ME is a separate co-processor that has full access to memory and networking. it's a complete blackbox and possibly a NSA backdoor. Officially, it's meant to enable admins remotely manage machines in an organization. But for a consumer, it serves no purpose at all apart from being a security, privacy and freedom risk.

You can't just desolder or overwrite it because PC will refuse to even boot if it doesn't detect ME.

Old intel CPUs didn't yet have ME, that's why libreboot only supports them and why you can only use very old hardware to be safe. There are things like me_cleaner and Purism that try to disable ME.

AMD has a counterpart called PSP - it's just as bad.

> [pexo](#comment_177_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): As far as I know they removed it from all their devices about a year ago(or half of one). They even got a notice from intel telling them to stop publishing the reverse engineered code, but they couldn't stop them from removing/neutralizing it without making their efforts public.

Just shows that Intel is either a complete scumbag OR they are forced by the NSA to protect their backdoor

> [redlibertyreal](#comment_22_1D6UcmziWg55aXV6TnCksXpjsFJ4gDK6Kw): Hacker here. For true hardcore mode get a Libreboot compatible pre-2008 computer. There are a lot of thinkpads that are Libreboot compatible, even some niche macbooks (ironically) that work. Just flash the BIOS chip (some you can do this for without having to open up the computer) with Libreboot and run a fully free OS such as Trisquel GNU/ Linux and you can be as close to 100% sure as possible that there are no software backdoors, even at the BIOS level. Of course if you're hardware is compromised you're fucked but that depends on your threat model. Falun Gong practitioner in China? Yeah... your hardware is probably fucked. Just a normal nerdy guy/ gal who likes IT? You're probably fine. That's up to you to figure out though. [...]

Do you think RISC-V has a chance of succeeding and becoming mainstream in home PCs?
